objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

Frederick Tathamprinter. "The Clod & the Pebble" (Bentley plate 32, object 55 as arranged in this copy) was probably printed by Tatham c. 1832. The hand coloring may be of an even later date and by an unknown hand. All other plates in this copy were printed and colored by Blake and his wife Catherine.

imprint.publisher: William Blake Blake's name is given as the "printer" on the title pages to Songs of Innocence and Songs of Experience, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not printed in the work, but Blake lived in London, and its suburb Lambeth, during the composition, etching, and printing of this copy.
imprint.date: 1789, 1794 The 1789 imprint appears on the title page to Songs of Innocence, the 1794 imprint on the title page to Songs of Experience. There is no date on the general, combined title page.

objdescid.compdate: 1789, 1794 1789 (objects 2-29, 34-37 as arranged in this copy), 1794 (objects 1, 30-33, 38-55 as arranged in this copy).

objinfo.printdate: 1789, 1794, 1795, c. 1832Blake assembled copy E for his patron Thomas Butts in 1806. Rather than printing new impressions from the copperplates, Blake gathered together impressions remaining from several earlier printings. Objects 2-28, 34-37 as arranged in this copy were probably printed in 1789. Objects 1, 29-33, 38-54 as arranged in this copy were probably printed in 1794 or 1795. Blake colored the plates, or added more coloring to plates previously colored, in 1806. "The Clod & the Pebble," object 55 as arranged in this copy, is a posthumous impression not part of Blake's original collation and numbering of the book. This plate was probably printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832; the coloring may be of a still later date by a different hand. "The Clod & the Pebble" was probably added by Frederick Locker between c. 1866 and 1886, when he owned the volume. He inscribed the object in pencil, "I inserted this— ?colouring more modern."
objinfo.objorder: Bentley plates 1-5, 25, 11, 8, 15, 9, 10, 54, 18, 12, 16, 17, 6, 7, 27, 22, 23, 53, 24, 19, 13, 14, 20, 21, 26, 28-31, 15, 34-36, 50, 37, 42, 46, 44, 39, 38, 41, 45, 47, 40, 49, 48, 51, 33, 43, 52, 32Bentley plate numbers are used here unless otherwise stated. Bentley plate 15, "Laughing Song," appears in both the "Innocence" and "Experience" sections of this copy, objects 9 and 34. Its repetition in the "Experience" section was probably caused by its presence on the recto of the only available (or at least minimally acceptable) impression of plate 34, "The Little Girl Lost," on hand in Blake's stock of prints. He apparently decided that it was preferable to repeat Bentley plate 15 in "Experience" rather than to exclude from this copy the three-plate sequence of "The Little Girl Lost" and "The Little Girl Found" (objects 35-37 as arranged in this copy). See the note following Print Date, above, for the later insertion of "The Clod & the Pebble," object 55 as arranged in this copy.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.4 x 7.9 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 32Objects 5-28 and 32-53 as arranged in this copy are printed recto/verso; all others are printed recto only. This copy contained 31 leaves as originally numbered and issued by Blake. See the note following Print Date, above, for the later insertion of "The Clod & the Pebble," object 55 as arranged in this copy. The volume also contained the following inserted materials: an anonymous two-page manuscript parody in purple ink entitled "A Song of Innonsense" (inserted before 1852), a three-page letter from Alexander Gilchrist dated 25 Oct. 1861 (apparently to Robert Arthington, then the owner of the volume), and a two-page transcription by Frederick Locker of a passage from Algernon Charles Swinburne, William Blake: A Critical Essay, 1868 (laid in loose by Locker between 1868 and 1886, when he owned the volume). These manuscripts are not included in this reproduction.
objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with color printing and hand coloringAt least small areas of color printing are evident on objects 31, 33, 38, 39, 42, 44-53 as arranged in this copy.
objinfo.inkcolor: raw sienna or yellow ochre or a mixture of the two (objects 1-24, 30-33, 39-53 as arranged in this copy), green (objects 25-28, 34-38 as arranged in this copy), gray-brown (object 29 as arranged in this copy), red (object 51 as arranged in this copy), burnt umber (object 54 as arranged in this copy), black (object 55 as arranged in this copy).
objinfo.watermark: WhatmanFragments of the watermark appear only in the leaves bearing objects 38/39 and 52/53 as arranged in this copy.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-54The numbers written by Blake in pen and ink appear top right on objects 1-54 as arranged in this copy.
objinfo.binding: disbound and matted in 1985Formerly bound in full green morocco by F. Bedford for Frederick Locker, who owned the volume between c. 1866 and 1886. This binding has been retained.
objinfo.stabholes: There are three sets of stab holes. The "Innocence" plates (objects 2-29 as arranged in this copy) show three holes 3.6 cm. and 3.3 cm. apart. Most of the "Innocence" plates show two further holes, 12.7 cm. apart, perhaps once used with one or more holes from the first group. The leaves bearing objects 42/43, 48/49, and 50/51 as arranged in this copy show three holes, 3.2 cm. and 3.9 cm. apart.

provenance.name: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery
provenance.note: Probably the copy purchased from Blake by Thomas Butts for £6.6s. on 9 Sept. 1806 (receipt now in the Huntington Library); sold from Butts' collection, Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 50, the book apparently bound in two volumes, with the anonymous parody poem (see the note following Number of Leaves, above) and a copy of the 1839 Pickering edition of Songs of Innocence and of Experience (£12.12s. to Robert Arthington); sold from Arthington's collection, Sotheby's, 17 May 1866, lot 17, with the additional materials included in the 1852 auction and Gilchrist's letter (see the note following Number of Leaves, above) inserted (£13.15s. to Basil M. Pickering, possibly acting for Frederick Locker, who added the posthumous impression of "The Clod & the Pebble," object 55 as arranged in this copy (Bentley plate 32), and listed the volume in his 1886 collection catalogue); E. Dwight Church, who purchased Locker's "Rowfant Library" en bloc; offered by Dodd, Mead & Company, The Rowfant Books catalogue of c. 1906, item 2, with the inserted materials listed in the note following Number of Leaves, above ($750); Beverly Chew; sold as part of Chew's collection to Henry E. Huntington in Dec. 1912.

desc.objtitle: General Title Page, object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude figures—the only vestiges of clothing are leafy vines around their loins—bend severely to the left, their bodies curved away from a powerful burst of flames and smoke(?) that extends all the way across the plate from the right margin. They seem to represent Adam and Eve being driven from the paradise in Eden. Eve, the long-haired lower figure, bends almost to a prone position, as if she has been crawling on the ground. Her right leg is drawn up under her and her left is extended behind. Her visible arm is extended under her head on the ground. Adam's body is bent over hers. His legs are spread and he clasps his head in his arms. The two bent bodies and the flames form concentric arches. The flames rise through the space between the lines of the title (lines 2-6) and subtitle (lines 7-8), then give way to flame- or smoke-like curls that reach into both upper corners of the plate. An ascending bird spreads its wings in the area to the right of the first "Of" (line 3). The initial "S" and the "N" of "SONGS" (line 2) have extravagant vine-like extensions. A tiny figure, apparently facing forward or right, with right arm raised vertically, stands on the lower, vine-like extension of the first "S" of "SONGS." To the right, also on the "S," is a seated figure, facing right and hunched over.

desc.objtitle: Introduction, object 4 (Bentley 4, Erdman 4, Keynes 4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, the front one gowned and seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude figure; (3) a standing figure, looking down; (4) an indistinct standing(?) figure; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves, above and below; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body; (7) a solitary standing figure with two flying birds; (8) possibly one or two seated figures. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

lg.l: Piping down the valleys wild
Piping songs of pleasant glee
On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb;
So I piped with merry chear,
Piper pipe that song again
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear,
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle: The Shepherd, object 5 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There may be a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hilltop in the background, where the light suggests that the time is sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the light. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird. There may be two even smaller birds perched on the limb below and to the right of those in flight.

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot,
From the morn to the evening he strays;
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call.
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace.
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle: Infant Joy, object 6 (Bentley 25, Erdman 25, Keynes 25)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 7). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.

lg.l: I have no name
I am but two days old.__
What shall I call thee?
I happy am
Joy is my name,__
Sweet joy befall thee!
Pretty joy!
Sweet joy but two days old,
Sweet joy I call thee;
Thou dost smile.
I sing the while
Sweet joy befall thee.

desc.objtitle: The Blossom, object 7 (Bentley 11, Erdman 11, Keynes 11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sitting on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title (line 2); (3) she seems to be holding an infant in her arms; (4) to her left, a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and probably reading or writing in a book or tablet; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from, and the other facing toward, the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. The tinting of the text area suggests a sunrise or sunset.

A happy Blossom
Sees you swift as arrow

lg.l: Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee clothing of delight,
Softest clothing wooly bright;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Making all the vales rejoice;
Little Lamb who made thee
Dost thou know who made thee
Little Lamb I'll tell thee,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Five figures sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them stands an eighth figure, a male in tights. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all but one of the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The three figures on the near side face away from the viewer toward the rest of the company. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 3, 7, 11-12). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the shadows on the ground, lower right.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh. with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene
When Mary and Susan and Emily.
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He.
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,

desc.objtitle: The Little Black Boy, object 10 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 11) mounts above the horizon in a rosy sky.

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day,
She took me on her lap and kissed me.
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun: there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space.,
That we may learn to bear the beams of love.
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care.

Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,

lg.l: Youth of delight come hither.
And see the opening morn,
Image of truth new-born
Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
Dark disputes & artful teazing,
Folly is an endless maze,

How many have fallen there:
They stumble all night over bones of the dead:
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
All pray in their distress:
And to these virtues of delight
Return their thankfulness.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is God our Father dear:
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
Pity, a human face:
And Love, the human form divine.
And Peace, the human dress.
Then every man of every clime.
That prays in his distress,
Prays to the human form divine
Love Mercy Pity Peace.
And all must love the human form.
In heathen, turk or jew,
Where Mercy. Love & Pity dwell
There God is dwelling too.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young.
And my father sold me while yet my tongue
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head
That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd, so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare,
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair
And so he was quiet. & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick, Joe Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key,
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.

And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind.

And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark

Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm.
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

lg.l: Sweet dreams form a shade,
O'er my lovely infants head,
Sweet dreams of pleasant streams.
By happy silent moony beams
Sweet sleep with soft down.
Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Sweet sleep Angel mild,
Hover o'er my happy child.
Sweet smiles in the night,
Hover over my delight.
Sweet smiles Mothers smiles
All the livelong night beguiles.
Sweet moans. dovelike sighs.
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
Sweet moans. sweeter smiles.
All the dovelike moans beguiles.
Sleep sleep happy child.
All creation slept and smil'd.
Sleep sleep. happy sleep.
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Sweet babe in thy face.
Holy image I can trace.
Sweet babe once like thee.
Thy maker lay and wept for me

The merry bells ring
To welcome the Spring.

Old John with white hair
Does laugh away care,

lg.l: Can I see anothers woe.
And not be in sorrow too.
Can I see anothers grief.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child.
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
Pouring pity in their breast.
And not sit the cradle near
Weeping tear on infants tear.
And not sit both night & day.
Wiping all our tears away.
O! no never can it be.
Never never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes an infant small.
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not. thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tear,
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone

Led by the wand'ring light,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west.
The evening star does shine.
The birds are silent in their nest.
And I must seek for mine,
The moon like a flower.
In heavens high bower;
With silent delight.
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves,
Where flocks have took delight;
Where lambs have nibbled, silent moves
The feet of angels bright;
Unseen they pour blessing,
And joy without ceasing,
On each bud and blossom.,
And each sleeping bosom.
They look in every thoughtless nest,
Where birds are coverd warm;
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm;
If they see any weeping.
That should have been sleeping
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for prey
They pitying stand and weep;
Seeking to drive their thirst away.
And keep them from the sheep.
But if they rush dreadful;
The angels most heedful,
Recieve each mild spirit.
New worlds to inherit.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold:
And pitying the tender cries.
And walking round the fold:
Saying: wrath by his meekness
And by his health. sickness.
Is driven away.
From our immortal day.
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name.
Graze after thee and weep.Blake wrote a "z" in pen over the "s" of the printed word "Grase", thereby changing it to "Graze".
For wash'd in life's river.
My bright mane for ever.
Shall shine like the gold.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade.
O'er my Angel-guarded bed.
That an Emmet lost it's way,
Where on grass methought I lay,
Troubled wilderd and folorn"folorn": i.e., "forlorn".
Dark benighted travel-worn,
Over many a tangled spray.
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh.
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
Pitying I drop'd a tear;
But I saw a glow-worm near:
Who replied. What wailing wight
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:
Follow now the beetles hum,
Little wanderer hie thee home.

lg.l: Hear the voice of the Bard!
Who Present, Past, & Future sees
Whose ears have heard,
The Holy Word,
That walk'd among the ancient trees.
Calling the lapsed Soul
And weeping in the evening dew:
That might controll.
The starry pole;
And fallen fallen light renew!
O Earth O Earth return!
Arise from out the dewy grass;
Night is worn,
And the morn.
Rises from the slumberous mass.
Turn away no more:
Why wilt thou turn away
The starry floor
The watry shore

lg.l: Earth raisd up her head.
From the darkness dread & drear.
Her light fled:
Stony dread!
And her locks cover'd with grey despair.
Prison'd on watry shore
Starry Jealousy does keep my den
Cold and hoar
Weeping o'er
I hear the father of the ancient men
Selfish father of men
Cruel jealous selfish fear
Can delight
Chain'd in night
The virgins of youth and morning bear.
Does spring hide its joy
When buds and blossoms grow?
Does the sower?
Sow by night?

Break this heavy chain.

Selfish! vain!
Eternal bane!

desc.objtitle: Laughing Song, object 34 (Bentley 15, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

objnote.p: Bentley plate 15, "Laughing Song," appears in both the "Innocence" and "Experience" sections of this copy. Its repetition here in the "Experience" section was probably caused by its presence on the recto of the only available (or at least minimally acceptable) impression of Bentley plate 34, "The Little Girl Lost," on hand in Blake's stock of prints. He apparently decided that it was preferable to repeat plate 15 in "Experience" rather than to exclude from this copy the three-plate sequence of "The Little Girl Lost" and "The Little Girl Found" (Bentley plates 34-36).

I prophetic see.
That the earth from sleep,
(Grave the sentence deep)
Shall arise and seek
For her maker meek:
And the desart wild
Become a garden mild.
In the southern clime,
Where the summers prime.
Never fades away;
Lovely Lyca lay.
Seven summers old
Lovely Lyca told,
She had wanderd long.
Hearing wild birds song. All but the first letter of "birds is poorly printed in this copy.
Sweet sleep come to me
Underneath this tree;
Do father, mother weep.__
"Where can Lyca sleep".
Lost in desart wild
Is your little child.
How can Lyca sleep.
If her mother weep.
If her heart does ake.
Then let Lyca wake;
If my mother sleep,
Lyca shall not weep.
Frowning frowning night.
O'er this desart bright.
Let thy moon arise,
While I close my eyes.
Sleeping Lyca lay;
While the beasts of prey,
Come from caverns deep,
View'd the maid asleep
The kingly lion stood
And the virgin view'd,

Round her as she lay;
While the lion old,
Bow'd his mane of gold,
And her bosom lick.
And upon her neck,
From his eyes of flame,
Ruby tears there came;
While the lioness.
Loos'd her slender dress,
And naked they convey'd
To caves the sleeping maid.
All the night in woe,
Lyca's parents go:
Over vallies deep.
While the desarts weep.
Tired and woe-begone.
Hoarse with making moan:

They trac'd the desart ways,

Among shadows deep:

With hollow piteous shriek
Rising from unrest,
The trembling woman prest,
With feet of weary woe;
She could no further go.
In his arms he bore.
Her arm'd with sorrow sore:
Till before their way.
A couching lion lay.
Turning back was vain,
Soon his heavy mane.
Bore them to the ground;
Then he stalk'd around.
Smelling to his prey.
But their fears allay.
When he licks their hands:
And silent by them stands.
They look upon his eyes
Fill'd with deep surprise:
And wondering behold.
A spirit arm'd in gold.
On his head a crown
On his shoulders down,
Flow'd his golden hair.
Gone was all their care.
Follow me he said,
Weep not for the maid;
In my palace deep,
Lyca lies asleep.
Then they followed,
Where the vision led:
And saw their sleeping child,
Among tygers wild.
To this day they dwell
In a lonely dell
Nor fear the wolvish howl,

Nor venerates another so,
Nor is it possible to thought
A greater than itself to know:
And Father, how can I love you,
Or any of my brothers more?
I love you like the little bird
That picks up crumbs around the door.
The Priest sat by and heard the child.
In trembling zeal he siez'd his hair:
He led him by his little coat;
And all admir'd the Priestly care.
And standing on the altar high.
Lo what a fiend is here! said he:
One who sets reason up for judge
Of our most holy Mystery.
The weeping child could not be heard.
The weeping parents wept in vain:
They strip'd him to his little shirt.
And bound him in an iron chain.
And burn'd him in a holy place.
Where many had been burn'd before:
The weeping parents wept in vain.

lg.l: A little black thing among the snow:
Crying weep, weep. in notes of woe!
Where are thy father & mother? say?
They are both gone up to the church to pray.

lg.l: Tyger Tyger. burning bright,
In the forests of the night:
What immortal hand or eye.
Could frame thy fearful symmetry?
In what distant deeps or skies.
Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
On what wings dare he aspire?
What the hand, dare sieze the fire?
And what shoulder, & what art,
Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
And when thy heart began to beat.
What dread hand? & what dread feet?
What the hammer? what the chain,
In what furnace was thy brain?
What the anvil? what dread grasp.
Dare its deadly terrors clasp!
When the stars threw down their spears
And water'd heaven with their tears:
Did he smile his work to see?
Did he who made the Lamb make thee?
Tyger Tyger burning bright,
In the forests of the night:
What immortal hand or eye,
Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?

Near where the charter'd Thames does flow

lg.l: I went to the Garden of Love.
And saw what I never had seen:
A Chapel was built in the midst,
Where I used to play on the green.
And the gates of this Chapel were shut,
And Thou shalt not. writ over the door;
So I turn'd to the Garden of Love,
That so many sweet flowers bore.
And I saw it was filled with graves,
And tomb-stones where flowers should be:
And Priests in black gowns, were walking their
rounds,
And binding with briars, my joys & desires.

lg.l: O Rose thou art sick.
The invisible worm.
That flies in the night
In the howling storm:
Has found out thy bed
Of crimson joy:

objnote.p: Blake printed this impression twice in an attempt to darken the very weak first printing of the text. The register was off in the second printing, slightly below and to the left of the first printing. The result is a double image, particularly noticeable in the vines and leaves right of the first stanza and between the two stanzas. For a full description of this double printing, see Robert N. Essick and Joseph Viscomi, "An Inquiry into William Blake's Method of Color Printing," Blake: An Illustrated Quarterly 35 (2002): 74-103.

lg.l: When the voices of children. are heard on the green
And whisprings are in the dale:
The days of my youth rise fresh in my mind,
My face turns green and pale
Then come home my children. the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Your spring & your day. are wasted in play

lg.l: I Dreamt a Dream! what can it mean?
And that I was a maiden Queen:
Guarded by an Angel mild:
Witless woe, was ne'er beguil'd!
And I wept both night and day
And he wip'd my tears away
And I wept both day and night
And hid from him my hearts delight
So he took his wings and fled:
Then the morn blush'd rosy red:
I dried my tears & arm'd my fears,
With ten thousand shields and spears.
Soon my Angel came again;
I was arm'd, he came in vain;
For the time of youth was fled
And grey hairs were on my head

lg.l: Dear Mother, dear Mother, the Church is cold.
But the Ale-house is healthy & pleasant & warm:
Besides I can tell where I am use'd well.
Such usage in heaven will never do well.
But if at the Church they would give us some Ale.
And a pleasant fire, our souls to regale:
We'd sing and we'd pray all the live-long day:
Nor ever once wish from the Church to stray.
Then the Parson might preach & drink & sing,
And we'd be as happy as birds in the spring:
And modest dame Lurch. who is always at Church,
Would not have bandy children nor fasting nor birch.
And God like a father rejoicing to see,
His children as pleasant and happy as he:
Would have no more quarrel with the Devil or the BarreThe "l" of "Barrel" was not etched on the plate, but was added with pen and ink in this copy.
But kiss him & give him both drink and apparel.

lg.l: Pity would be no more,
If we did not make somebody Poor;
And Mercy no more could be.
If all were as happy as we;
And mutual fear brings peace;
Till the selfish loves increase.
Then Cruelty knits a snare,
And spreads his baits with care.
He sits down with holy fears,
And waters the ground with tears:
Then Humility takes its root
Underneath his foot.
Soon spreads the dismal shade
Of Mystery over his head;
And the Catterpiller and Fly,
Feed on the Mystery.
And it bears the fruit of Deceit,
Ruddy and sweet to eat;
And the Raven his nest has made
In its thickest shade.
The Gods of the earth and sea,
Sought thro' Nature to find this Tree
But their search was all in vain;
There grows one in the Human Brain

lg.l: Little Fly
Thy summers play.
My thoughtless hand
Has brush'd away.
Am not I
A fly like thee?
Or art not thou
A man like me?
For I dance
And drink & sing;
Till some blind hand
Shall brush my wing.
If thought is life
And strength & breath;
And the want
Of thought is death;
Then am I
A happy fly,
If I live,
Or if I die.

lg.l: I was angry with my friend;
I told my wrath, my wrath did end.
I was angry with my foe:
I told it not. my wrath did grow.
And I waterd it in fears,
Night & morning with my tears:
And I sunned it with smiles,
And with soft deceitful wiles.
And it grew both day and night,
Till it bore an apple bright.
And my foe beheld it shine,
And he knew that it was mine.
And into my garden stole,
When the night had veild the pole:
In the morning glad I see;
My foe outstretchd beneath the tree.

Know that in a former time,
Love! sweet Love! was thought a crime.
In the Age of Gold,
Free from winters cold:
Youth and maiden bright.
To the holy light,
Naked in the sunny beams delight.
Once a youthful pair
Fill'd with softest care;
Met in garden bright.
Where the holy light,
Had just removd the curtains of the night.
There in rising day,
On the grass they play:
Parents were afar:
Strangers came not near:

lg.l: Is this a Holy thing to see.
In a rich and fruitful land.
Babes reducd to misery,
Fed with cold and usurous hand?
Is that trembling cry a song?
Can it be a song of joy?
And so many children poor?
It is a land of poverty!
And their sun does never shine.
And their fields are bleak & bare.
And their ways are fill'd with thorns.
It is eternal winter there.
For where-e'er the sun does shine.
And where-e'er the rain does fall;
Babe can never hunger there,
Nor poverty the mind appall.

lg.l: A flower was offerd to me;
Such a flower as May never bore.
But I said I've a Pretty Rose-tree.
And I passed the sweet flower o'er.
Then I went to my Pretty Rose-tree:
To tend her by day and by night.
But my Rose turnd away with jealousy:
And her thorns were my only delight.
Ah Sun-flower! weary of time,
Who countest the steps of the Sun:
Seeking after that sweet golden clime.
Where the travellers journey is done.
Where the Youth pined away with desire,
And the pale Virgin shrouded in snow:
Arise from their graves and aspire.
Where my Sun-flower wishes to go.
The modest Rose puts forth a thorn:
The humble Sheep, a threatning horn:
While the Lilly white. shall in Love delight.
Nor a thorn nor a threat stain her beauty

To rise from Generation free;

The Sexes sprung from Shame & Pride

But Mercy changd Death into Sleep;
The Sexes rose to work & weep.
Thou Mother of my Mortal part.
With cruelty didst mould my Heart,
And with false self-decieving tears,
Didst bind my Nostrils Eyes & Ears

lg.l: Love seeketh not Itself to please.
Nor for itself hath any care;
But for another gives its ease.
And builds a Heaven in Hells despair,
So sung a little Clod of Clay.
Trodden with the cattles feet:
But a Pebble of the brook.
Warbled out these metres meet.
Love seeketh only Self to please,
To bind another to Its delight;
Joys in anothers loss of ease,
And builds a Hell in Heavens despite.
